title: Free Energy Principle in Biological Systems
description: Application of the Free Energy Principle to biological self-organization, homeostasis, and evolution.
learning_objectives: Analyze biological self-organization through FEP lens

content.overview: The Free Energy Principle provides a unifying framework for understanding how biological systems maintain their structural and functional integrity. This section explores applications to physiological regulation, evolution, and biological self-organization.

homeostatic_regulation.set_points: Reference states that systems try to maintain
homeostatic_regulation.control_mechanisms: Negative feedback loops minimize prediction errors
homeostatic_regulation.allostatic_regulation: Adaptive set points based on environmental demands

physiological_systems.description: Body temperature control through free energy minimization
physiological_systems.mechanism: Hypothalamus predicts and controls core temperature
Pancreas and liver predict and regulate glucose levels
physiological_systems.corrective_actions: Insulin release, glucagon release, feeding behavior

physiological_systems.mechanism: Baroreceptors predict and maintain pressure set points
physiological_systems.corrective_actions: Heart rate, vessel dilation, fluid retention

evolutionary_perspective.natural_selection: Organisms that minimize free energy are more likely to survive
evolutionary_perspective.niche_construction: Organisms modify environment to reduce free energy
evolutionary_perspective.adaptive_fitness: Fitness landscapes as free energy landscapes
evolutionary_perspective.evolutionary_stability: Evolution toward free energy minimizing strategies

neural_implementation.learning: Synaptic plasticity reduces free energy over time
neural_implementation.development: Neural development as free energy minimization

examples.name: Single-Cell Organism
examples.principle: Move to minimize prediction errors about optimal conditions

examples.name: Plant Tropisms
examples.description: Plants growing toward light and nutrients
examples.principle: Growth patterns minimize free energy in environment

examples.name: Immune System
examples.mechanism: Immune cells predict and eliminate threats
examples.principle: Inflammation as response to prediction errors

connections_to_active_inference.perception_action_cycle: FEP unifies perception and action in biological systems
connections_to_active_inference.allostasis: Predictive regulation of physiological set points
connections_to_active_inference.niche_construction: Active modification of environment to minimize free energy

FEP operates at all levels from cells to conscious organisms
Natural selection favors free energy minimizing organisms
